description:
Motacilla alba alba, commonly known as the Western White Wagtail, is a subspecies of the White Wagtail (Motacilla alba), a small passerine bird belonging to the Motacillidae family. The Western White Wagtail is found in Europe and parts of Asia, including Western and Central Europe, Scandinavia, and Western Asia.

This subspecies is characterized by its distinctive black-and-white plumage, with a black head, back, and tail, and white underparts and wing bars. The bird's long, slender bill and tail, which it frequently wags up and down, are also notable features. The Western White Wagtail is an agile and opportunistic forager, feeding primarily on insects and other small invertebrates found in its various habitats, which can include open areas, farmlands, and wetlands.

The Western White Wagtail is known for its migratory behavior, with some populations undertaking seasonal movements between breeding and wintering grounds. It is a common and widespread species, and its population is considered to be stable, with the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) classifying it as a species of Least Concern.
